> Then I'll leave you with this final thought:  If we design 
> software by writing tests first, do the tests document the 
> intention of the software, or its implementation?
> 

But this assumes that our tests cover all possibilities of use, which can
result in large test suites. I am not against this (in fact I prefer it),
but often a few words of English (or whatever language you read) is
preferrable (IMHO) to a large test suite.
I still have the test suite, however, for refactoring and code proof.

I would still say that that the tests document examples of the intention,
rather than the intention itself. These examples may be a complete set or
may not be, often just the critical subset.

cheers
joe
